info.headline: Flood Warning issued January 09 at 4:20PM EST until January 11 at 4:00PM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg SC has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in North Carolina... French Broad River At Marshall affecting Madison County. .Heavy rain has ended across Madison County. However, storm-total rainfall of 2-3.5 inches occurred across the county with more significant rainfall of 6-7 inches occurring in the headwaters of the French Broad River. Therefore, very high local and upstream flows are causing significant rises along the French Broad River with nuisance to Minor flooding along the river from Marshall to Hot Springs underway. This will result in common, deeper flooding of low-lying areas adjacent to the French Broad River with lesser impacts to vulnerable property. Residents are advised to move vulnerable property to higher ground and stay up-to-date by monitoring the latest river levels and forecasts. ...FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT UNTIL THURSDAY AFTERNOON... ...REPLACES RIVER FLOOD ADVISORY... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...French Broad River at Marshall. * WHEN...Until Thursday afternoon. * IMPACTS...At 8.0 feet, Minor Flood Stage. The French Broad River may be approaching some buildings on Blannahassett Island and approaching residential yards along Island Road. Flooding along the lowest elevations of Rollins Road is possible. The river may be approaching the railroad tracks in the Back Street area. At 9.0 feet, Minor flooding continues. The French Broad River may be approaching the railroad tracks and starting to flood areas between Highway 70 and the normal riverbank. Floodwaters may begin to reach buildings along Back Street and on Blannahassett Island. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 4:01 PM EST Tuesday the stage was 7.9 feet and rising steadily. - Action/Advisory Stage is 7.5 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage late this afternoon to a crest of 9.5 feet tomorrow morning. It will then fall below flood stage early Thursday morning. - Minor Flood Stage is 8.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. Even 6 inches of fast-moving flood water can knock you off your feet and a depth of 2 feet will float your car. Never try to walk, swim, or drive through such swift water. If you come upon flood waters, stop, turn around and go another way. For detailed information including observed and forecast stages, flood impacts, flood history, FEMA Flood Hazard Layers, and more, please visit: https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=gsp The next statement will be issued before Thursday afternoon at 400 PM EST.
